title: Dissecting the Ransomless AntiWar Malware: Zero Demand for Ransom

chapters.title: Dissecting the Ransomless AntiWar Malware: Zero Demand for Ransom

sentences.text: The geopolitical crisis between Russia and Ukraine has fueled multiple cyberattacks across the world. While monitoring for the latest cyber incidents that are part of the ongoing cyber warfare, the Cyble Research Labs recently came across a ransomware sample allegedly targeting Russia. Whats interesting is that instead of demanding ransom, this ransomware sends out a message to stop the war.
sentences.html: The geopolitical crisis between Russia and Ukraine has fueled multiple cyberattacks across the world. While monitoring for the latest cyber incidents that are part of the ongoing cyber warfare, the Cyble Research Labs recently came across a ransomware sample allegedly targeting Russia. What’s interesting is that instead of demanding ransom, this ransomware sends out a message to stop the war.

sentences.text: Upon execution, the ransomware renames encrypted files with the .putinwillburnunhell extension. While typically ransomware drops a .txt file as a ransom note, in this case, we saw a .html file named RUSSKIJ VOENNIJ KORABL IDI NAHUJ, which when translated in English means RUSSIAN WARSHIP GO F**K.
sentences.html: Upon execution, the ransomware renames encrypted files with the “.putinwillburnunhell” extension. While typically ransomware drops a .txt file as a ransom note, in this case, we saw a .html file named “RUSSKIJ VOENNIJ KORABL IDI NAHUJ”, which when translated in English means “RUSSIAN WARSHIP GO F**K”.

sentences.text: Our Open Source Intelligence (OSINT) analysis shows that Poland is the source of the sample. The message in the HTML file indicates that the ransomware may be targeting Russia, as shown in Figure 1.
sentences.html: Our Open Source Intelligence (OSINT) analysis shows that Poland is the source of the sample. The message in the HTML file indicates that the ransomware may be targeting Russia, as shown in Figure 1.

sentences.text: Figure 1 Message in a Dropped file (Translated from Russian)

Cyble Research Labs performed an analysis of the sample with the hash value: 9f3c1668ee44bfcd1afd599215f5bd73c76609776b78cb04bb6ef1121cc80d37. Our research indicated that the malware is an x64 architecture Windows binary written in C/C++ and compiled on 2022-03-04 at 15:17:53.
sentences.html: Cyble Research Labs performed an analysis of the sample with the hash value: 9f3c1668ee44bfcd1afd599215f5bd73c76609776b78cb04bb6ef1121cc80d37. Our research indicated that the malware is an x64 architecture Windows binary written in C/C++ and compiled on 2022-03-04 at 15:17:53.​

sentences.text: Figure 2 File Information

We observed that the malware first changes the priority of the process to zero by calling the SetProcessShutdownParameters() API so that the malwares activities can be terminated only before the system shutdown. This is a way to increase the amount of time the malware gets to execute in the compromised machine.
sentences.html: ​We observed that the malware first changes the priority of the process to zero by calling the SetProcessShutdownParameters() API so that the malware’s activities can be terminated only before the system shutdown. This is a way to increase the amount of time the malware gets to execute in the compromised machine.

sentences.text: Figure 3 Malware Changes the Priority of the Process

The ransomware enumerates services in the compromised system and terminates those services that are actively running in the victims machine. Some of these services include VSS, SQL, Memtas, mepocs, etc.
sentences.html: The ransomware enumerates services in the compromised system and terminates those services that are actively running in the victim’s machine. Some of these services include VSS, SQL, Memtas, mepocs, etc.

sentences.text: To identify the services in the victims machine, it calls the OpenSCManagerA() API, which establishes a connection to the service control manager and gives the malware access to the service control manager database, as shown in Figure 4.
sentences.html: To identify the services in the victim’s machine, it calls the OpenSCManagerA() API, which establishes a connection to the service control manager and gives the malware access to the service control manager database, as shown in Figure 4.

sentences.text: Figure 4 Establishes a Connection to the Service Control Manager

The ransomware also enumerates the running processes and terminates processes that are actively running in the victims machine. The process names checked by the ransomware include oracle.exe, ocssd.exe, dbsnmp.exe, synctime.exe, etc.
sentences.html: The ransomware also enumerates the running processes and terminates processes that are actively running in the victim’s machine. The process names checked by the ransomware include oracle.exe, ocssd.exe, dbsnmp.exe, synctime.exe, etc.

sentences.text: Figure 5 Terminates Active Processes
The malware calls the SHEmptyRecycleBinA() API to empty the Recycle Bin as a step to ensure that deleted files cannot be restored after encryption.
sentences.html: The malware calls the SHEmptyRecycleBinA() API to empty the Recycle Bin as a step to ensure that deleted files cannot be restored after encryption.

sentences.text: Our research indicated that the ransomware tries to open a mutex named Microsoft Corporation in an infected machine. If the mutex name is not present, the malware creates the same mutex name and continues with its infection process.
sentences.html: Our research indicated that the ransomware tries to open a mutex named “Microsoft Corporation” in an infected machine. If the mutex name is not present, the malware creates the same mutex name and continues with its infection process.

sentences.text: Figure 6 Checks and Creates Mutex if not Present
After creating the mutex, the malware then begins the encryption process by identifying the volumes in an infected machine.
sentences.html: After creating the mutex, the malware then begins the encryption process by identifying the volumes in an infected machine.

sentences.text: Figure 7 Starts Encryption
It also identifies the mounted local drives by enumerating them from A to Z, as shown in Figure 8.
sentences.html: It also identifies the mounted local drives by enumerating them from A to Z, as shown in Figure 8.

sentences.text: Figure 8 Enumerates Local Drives
This is followed by the malware encrypting the files present in all of the identified drives with the exception of CD-ROM, as shown in Figure 9.
sentences.html: This is followed by the malware encrypting the files present in all of the identified drives with the exception of CD-ROM, as shown in Figure 9.

sentences.text: Figure 9 Encrypts the Files present in all the Identified Drives Except CD-ROM

Before initiating encryption, the ransomware checks and excludes specific folders from encryption, such as AppData, Boot, Windows, Windows.old, Tor Browser, Internet Explorer, Google, Opera, Opera Software, Mozilla, Mozilla Firefox, ProgramData, Program Files, and Program Files (x86).
sentences.html: Before initiating encryption, the ransomware checks and excludes specific folders from encryption, such as AppData, Boot, Windows, Windows.old, Tor Browser, Internet Explorer, Google, Opera, Opera Software, Mozilla, Mozilla Firefox, ProgramData, Program Files, and Program Files (x86).

sentences.text: It also excludes certain files from encryption, such as autorun.inf, boot.ini, bootfont.bin, bootsect.bak, bootmgr, bootmgr.efi, bootmgfw.efi, desktop.ini, iconcache.db, ntldr, and ntuser.dat.
sentences.html: It also excludes certain files from encryption, such as autorun.inf, boot.ini, bootfont.bin, bootsect.bak, bootmgr, bootmgr.efi, bootmgfw.efi, desktop.ini, iconcache.db, ntldr, and ntuser.dat.

sentences.text: Additionally, specific extensions are also exempted from encryption, including .putinwillburninhell, .hta, .exe, .dll, .cpl, .ini, .cab, .cur, .drv, .hlp, .icl, .icns, .ico, .idx, .sys, .spl, .ocx.
sentences.html: Additionally, specific extensions are also exempted from encryption, including .putinwillburninhell, .hta, .exe, .dll, .cpl, .ini, .cab, .cur, .drv, .hlp, .icl, .icns, .ico, .idx, .sys, .spl, .ocx.

sentences.text: After encrypting the files on the victims machine, the malware appends them with the extension .putinwillburninhell and drops an HTML file with the name RUSSKIJ VOENNIJ KORABL IDI NAHUJ as shown in Figure 10.
sentences.html: After encrypting the files on the victim’s machine, the malware appends them with the extension “.putinwillburninhell” and drops an HTML file with the name “RUSSKIJ VOENNIJ KORABL IDI NAHUJ” as shown in Figure 10.

sentences.text: Figure 10 Encrypted Files on the Victims Machine

With the geopolitical crisis causing a surge in cyberattacks across the world, ransomware has emerged as a serious threat worldwide. As a result of the ongoing cyber warfare, we have witnessed an uptick in the use of ransomware and data wiper malware targeting both nations in conflict. Threat Actors are also devising attack techniques of increasing sophistication.
sentences.html: ​With the geopolitical crisis causing a surge in cyberattacks across the world, ransomware has emerged as a serious threat worldwide. As a result of the ongoing cyber warfare, we have witnessed an uptick in the use of ransomware and data wiper malware targeting both nations in conflict. Threat Actors are also devising attack techniques of increasing sophistication.

sentences.text: With cybercrime on the rise, it is imperative for organizations to strengthen their security posture. Our researchers are continuously gathering more information on the latest cyberattacks, and we will keep updating this space as and when we have more information.
sentences.html: With cybercrime on the rise, it is imperative for organizations to strengthen their security posture. Our researchers are continuously gathering more information on the latest cyberattacks, and we will keep updating this space as and when we have more information.

sentences.text: We have listed some essential cybersecurity best practices that create the first line of control against attackers. We recommend that our readers follow the best practices given below:
sentences.html: ​We have listed some essential cybersecurity best practices that create the first line of control against attackers. We recommend that our readers follow the best practices given below:

chapters.title: Safety measures needed to prevent ransomware attacks

sentences.text: Conduct regular backup practices and keep those backups offline or in a separate network.<crlf>Turn on the automatic software update feature on your computer, mobile, and other connected devices wherever possible and pragmatic.<crlf>Use a reputed anti-virus and Internet security software package on your connected devices, including PC, laptop, and mobile.<crlf>Refrain from opening untrusted links and email attachments without verifying their authenticity.
sentences.html:
• Conduct regular backup practices and keep those backups offline or in a separate network.
  • Turn on the automatic software update feature on your computer, mobile, and other connected devices wherever possible and pragmatic. 
  • Use a reputed anti-virus and Internet security software package on your connected devices, including PC, laptop, and mobile.
  • Refrain from opening untrusted links and email attachments without verifying their authenticity.

sentences.text: Loss of valuable data<crlf>Loss of reputation<crlf>Loss of critical businesses information<crlf>Disruption in an organizations operation<crlf>Financial loss
sentences.html:
• Loss of valuable data
  • Loss of reputation
  • Loss of critical businesses information
  • Disruption in an organization’s operation
  • Financial loss
